awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Healthy and Safe Aging (ERC-HSA)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program.  Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

Between 2016 and 2050, the number of older adults (age>65) in the US will grow from 49 million to 84 million. The combination of the growing aging population with increasingly complex care needs presents a major societal challenge to deliver safe, effective and efficient health care. While older adults prefer to stay in their home or a familiar environment, they also require health services, but are at high risk for patient safety issues and healthcare-associated harm when interacting with the healthcare delivery system. We need to develop technologies that can help older adults stay healthy and safe longer: this includes supporting safe interactions of older adults with the healthcare system (e.g. emergency room, hospital). We plan to develop an ERC for Healthy and Safe Aging (ERC-HSA) that will engage multiple disciplines (engineering, health sciences) and older adults and their caregivers to develop older-care-application-specific smart sensing technologies and integrate them into the overall coordinated older adult care system. The proposed ERC-HSA will be integrated in the newly created Wisconsin Institute for Healthcare Systems Engineering at UW-Madison and will benefit from complementary expertise of researchers at other Universities. During the ERC planning stage, we will work with various universities and local groups to develop strategies and programs aimed at enhancing diversity of our future students and addressing ageism, i.e. biases targeted at older adults. We will also build stronger ties with the health technology industry in the Greater Madison area as well as along the ?Health Highway?, a 600-mile Midwestern stretch that spans four states and represents a growing healthcare ecosystem.

The proposed ERC-HSA will develop a convergent research agenda organized around expertise in sensor technologies, data analytics and system design that will be combined with deep knowledge about aging care to develop technologies that effectively address the societal problem of healthy and safe aging. With advice of experts in strategic planning, team science, diversity and aging, we will coordinate various activities, including webinar on team science and team research, targeted roundtables and a workshop with industry. We will organize roundtables to develop the innovative convergent research program and create opportunities for conversations among researchers from various backgrounds. Older adults and their caregivers and healthcare professionals will actively participate in these activities as we propose to do research not on older adults, but with and for older adults. We will blend expertise in three thrust areas: (1) human-centered modeling, simulation and design of patient work and clinical workflow, (2) health/healthcare data analytics, and (3) sensors and sensing technologies. Our goal is to go beyond designing siloed and fragmented technologies and promote innovative convergent research that will design the next generation of technologies for healthy and safe aging.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Transforming care processes and improving health can have major socio-economic impacts on one of the largest industrial sectors: health care. This is critical as the population of older adults (age>65) grows from 49 million in the 2016 to 84 million in 2050, and their complex care needs quickly exceed the capacity of existing care models. Reaping the benefits of the digital technology revolution to support the needs of the aging population demands investment in developing a new model for convergent research in Healthy and Safe Aging (HSA) that combines expertise in engineering with health and social sciences. To achieve this, we proposed to develop an Engineering Research Center for Healthy and Safe Aging (ERC-HSA) whose vision was to create the next generation of HSA engineering solutions that build bridges between clinical and caregiving groups who care for older adults. We successfully assembled a convergent research team to develop the ERC-HSA by: (1) combining various engineering, clinical and social expertise areas, (2) including the voice of the patient, and (3) bridging the gap between health and health care, i.e. connecting daily life with health care encounters. ERC-HSA is integrated in the Wisconsin Institute for Healthcare Systems Engineering at UW-Madison and collaborated with four core university partner institutions: University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Purdue University, University of South Florida and the University of Puerto Rico at Mayaguez, as well as a range of industrial partners in the health care delivery and health technology domains.

 

As a transdisciplinary team of researchers, we developed the ERC-HSA plan for convergent research that combines fundamental and technological knowledge with expertise in health and social sciences, policy (e.g. reimbursement, inter-operability, cyber-security) and regulation, and was organized into three themes: (1) multi-modal sensing technologies for HSA at home; (2) multi-type data harnessing and sensemaking for older adults, caregivers and clinicians; and (3) integration and implementation of patient- and clinician-centered technologies for safe care delivery. The ERC-HSA helped us to identify mechanisms for translating HSA engineering solutions into practice as we collaborated with older adults, caregivers, clinicians, and health/health care technology industry.

 

Although the pre-proposal for the ERC-HSA was not selected for full proposal development, members of our transdisciplinary team continue to discuss and develop collaborative research opportunities. The Interdisciplinary Symposium, ?Detecting and Managing Balance and Mobility Phenotypes Using Next Generation Technologies: Artificial Intelligence, Biomechanical Sensing, and Beyond?, was held on October 30, 2020. This was a collaboration between the Wisconsin Institute for Healthcare Systems Engineering (WIHSE, the home of the NSF ERC planning grant) and the Institute for Clinical Translational Research at UW-Madison. This interdisciplinary symposium convened 49 UW-Madison researchers and clinicians in the areas of artificial intelligence, sensing technologies, clinical medicine, kinesiology, and other health fields to: 1) increase awareness of state-of-the-art research being conducted at UW-Madison, 2) create an interdisciplinary research community focused on advancing scholarship on balance and mobility, and 3) foster and support new interdisciplinary research resulting in funding and health system interventions.

 

Intellectual merit:

This project led to the development of a transdisciplinary research agenda aimed at developing innovative and transformative technological solutions for HSA (Healthy and Safe Aging). There is continued interaction between multiple engineering disciplines (e.g. industrial and systems engineering, electrical and computer engineering, mechanical engineering), health sciences (e.g. health services research, geriatrics, nursing, pharmacy) and many other disciplines around the themes of the transdisciplinary research agenda. This includes a symposium focused on AI and sensing that brought together almost 50 researchers and contributed to the development of new research ideas and potential grant proposals.

 

Broader impacts:

This project addressed the major societal challenge of the increasing aging population with its complex care needs, which are quickly exceeding the capacity of current care models. We address this challenge by developing a transdisciplinary research agenda in close collaboration with older adults and their caregivers. This research development process fits with the citizen science movement and takes advantage of the large knowledge and experience of older adults and their caregivers. In addition, the research development process involved the future producers of knowledge and technologies, in particular undergraduate and graduate students in engineering. They participated in multiple activities, such as workshops and focus groups.
